data.sampled:
Subject: Long Thoracic Nerve
When Long Thoracic Nerve is being affected You can find the Long Thoracic Nerve just before the lower tip of your collarbone by You can find the Long Thoracic Nerve just before the lower tip of your collarbone by You can find the Long Thoracic Nerve just before the lower tip of your collarbone by locating the apex of your Aerophagus at the same level on your chest.</s> 
What are the possible symptoms one can experience when the Long Thoracic Nerve is affected?</s> 
Symptoms of Long Thoracic Nerve damage can include:
- Pain or numbness in the chest or upper back
- Difficulty breathing
- Loss of sensation in the upper arm
- Weakness in the arm or hand
- Horner's Syndrome, characterized by drooping of the eyelid, constriction of the pupil, and even sweating in the face.
- Chronic pain in the chest or upper back.
